commit_message:
Intent-based Service Chaining specification

Change-Id: Iaf93e186ea94ae1cb74592c2519f0d946e62c6ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/81/176981/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= Intent Based Service Chaining ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/intent-based-service-chaining The Intent-based API for Service Chaining allows client applications to prescribe the sequence of service functions that need to be applied to traffic between a source endpoint and a destination endpoint. Problem description =================== Current in data centers, the deployment of service chain for a tenant's flow is through static, complex, and rigid configurations since they are tightly coupled with network topology and physical resources. The introduction of new services into a network usually requires the reconfiguration of most (if not all) network elements. The reconfiguration is complex, time-consuming, and error-prone, requiring careful planning of topology changes and network outages, and incurring high OPEX on the user side. A simple intent based user interface and a SDN based service chaining framework is needed to solve these challenges for operators and service providers. Proposed change =============== A new Intent-based Service Chaining API is proposed which allows the client applications to prescribe the sequence of service functions that need to be applied to traffic between a source endpoint and a destination endpoint. This Intent API is based on an Intent model which includes the following entities: 1. Intent. An Intent is used to determine how the traffic between source composite EP, and destination composite endpoint is to be treated. An Intent consists of the source Composite Endpoint, the destination Composite Endpoint, and Intent Operations. 2. Intent Operation. This is the operation applied to the traffic that matches the source and destination composite endpoints. An operation may refer to a service chain, access control, a QoS operation, etc. 3. Composite Endpoint (CEP). A composite endpoint consists of a Boolean expression consisting of operands (terms) and the Boolean operators: and, or, not. The Boolean operands are registered endpoint descriptor ids and/or the ids of other composite Endpoints. Parentheses may be used for the purpose of grouping. For example: Composite EP expression = "(EPD1 or EPD2) and not CEP22" 4. Endpoint Descriptor (EPD). Each endpoint descriptor has a type and value that are used to partially identify the endpoint. The EP descriptor id is used as an operand (term) in a composite EP's Boolean expression. The type of the endpoint descriptor may be a base networking identifier, such as Layer 3 IP address, or a user-defined type. The value may a single value, a range of values, or a group of values. 5. Service Chain Specification. This is a Service Chain specification associated with the “ServiceChain” Intent Operation. The specification consists of an ordered list of Service Functions. This work is intended to be done during the Liberty release. REST API -------- A. Intent The attributes of the Intent resource are shown below. +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |CRUD|Description | |Name | | |Value | | | +===========+==========+========+=========+====+===================+ |id |uuid-str |RO, all |generated|R |identity | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |tenant_id |uuid-str |RO, all |from auth|CR |Tenant Id | | | | |token | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | | | | | | |name | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |description|string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |src |uuid-str |RW, all |None |CRU |Source | |_composite | | | | |composite endpoint | |_endpoint | | | | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |dst |uuid-str |RW, all |None |CRU |Destination | |_composite | | | | |composite endpoint | |_endpoint | | | | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |operations |List |RW, all |None |CRU |List of operations | | |(uuid-str)| | | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ B. Composite Endpoint The attributes of the Composite Endpoint resource are shown below. +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |CRUD|Description | |Name | | |Value | | | +===========+==========+========+=========+====+===================+ |id |uuid-str |RO, all |generated|R |identity | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |tenant_id |uuid-str |RO, all |from auth|CR |Tenant Id | | | | |token | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | | | | | | |name | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |description|string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |expression |string |RW, all |None |CRU |Boolean expression | | | | | | |of registered EP | | | | | | |descriptor ids and/| | | | | | |or CEP ids that use| | | | | | |operators: and, or,| | | | | | |not | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ C. Endpoint Descriptor The attributes of the Endpoint Descriptor resource are shown below. +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |CRUD|Description | |Name | | |Value | | | +===========+==========+========+=========+====+===================+ |id |uuid-str |RO, all |generated|R |identity | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |tenant_id |uuid-str |RO, all |from auth|CR |Tenant Id | | | | |token | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | | | | | | |name | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |description|string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |type |Enum |RW, all |Allow |CRU |Descriptor type | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |format |Enum |RW, all |0 |CRU |Format:single-val, | | | | | | |range, list | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |value |List(dict)|RW, all |None |CRU |Value | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ D. Intent Operation The attributes of the Intent Operation resource are shown below. +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |CRUD|Description | |Name | | |Value | | | +===========+==========+========+=========+====+===================+ |id |uuid-str |RO, all |generated|R |identity | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |tenant_id |uuid-str |RO, all |from auth|CR |Tenant Id | | | | |token | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | | | | | | |name | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |description|string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |type |Enum |RW, all |Allow |CRU |Operation type: | | | | | | |service-chain,qos | | | | | | |allow,inspect,log | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |value |List(dict)|RW, all |None |CRU |Value | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ E. Service Chain The attributes of the Service Chain resource are shown below. +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |CRUD|Description | |Name | | |Value | | | +===========+==========+========+=========+====+===================+ |id |string |RO, all |generated|R |identity | | |(UUID) | | | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |tenant_id |uuid |RO, all |from auth|CR |Tenant Id | | | | |token | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | | | | | | |name | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |description|string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |service |List(uuid)|RW, all |Empty |CRU |List of service | |_functions | | | | |function entities | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |direction |Enum |RW, all |None |CRU |direction: bidir, | | | | | | |forward, reverse | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ F. Service Function Entity The attributes of the Service Function Entity resource are shown below. +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |CRUD|Description | |Name | | |Value | | | +===========+==========+========+=========+====+===================+ |id |string |RO, all |generated|R |identity | | |(UUID) | | | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |tenant_id |uuid |RO, all |from auth|CR |Tenant Id | | | | |token | | | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | | | | | | |name | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |description|string |RW, all |'' |CRU |human-readable | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |type |Enum |RW, all |Allow |CRU |SF type: FW, DPI, | | | | | | |WANopt, DPI, NAT, | | | | | | |LB, TCPopt, HTTPenh| +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ |flavor |String |RW, all |None |CRU |Flavor qualifier | +-----------+----------+--------+---------+----+-------------------+ Alternatives ------------ There are no proposed alternatives to what is proposed in this document. Data model impact ----------------- Migration scripts will be added to support the new resources. REST API impact --------------- intent.py will include the following sections:: RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = { DESCRIPTORS: { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'default': '', 'is_visible': True}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'default': '', 'is_visible': True}, 'format': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'convert_to': convert_format, 'validate': {'type:values': supported_formats}}, 'values': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string_list': None}, 'default': [], 'is_visible': True}, }, COMPOSITE_ENDPOINTS: { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'default': '', 'is_visible': True}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'required_by_intent': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'expression': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'default': None, 'is_visible': True}, }, INTENT_OPERATIONS: { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'default': '', 'is_visible': True}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'required': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'operation_type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'convert_to': convert_operation_to_case_insensitive, 'validate': {'type:values': intent_supported_operations}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': 'allow'}, 'operation_value': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None}, 'is_visible': True}, }, INTENTS: { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'default': '', 'is_visible': True}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'required': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'source_endpoint': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None}, 'required': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'destination_endpoint': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None}, 'required': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'intent_operations': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None}, 'convert_to': attr.convert_none_to_empty_list, 'required': True, 'is_visible': True}, }, } Security impact --------------- Existing security for Neutron applies. Notifications impact -------------------- No change. Other end user impact --------------------- Sample CLI commands for creating Intent:: intent-create -–intent-operations "op1" --src-composite-endpoint "CEP1" --dst-composite-endpoint "CEP2" intent-operation-create -–type “service-chain” -–value "service-chain1" "op1" intent-endpoint-descriptor-create --name "IP1" -–type IP-address --value "10.1.2.3" intent-endpoint-descriptor-create --name "portrangeX" -–type port-range --value "1100-2200" intent-composite-endpoint-create -–expression "IP1 & portrangeX" "CEP1" intent-service-function-create --type "firewall" "SF1" intent-service-chain-create --functions "SF1" "service-chain1" Changes will be made to python-neutronclient to support this CLI. Changes will also be made to Horizon and Heat. Performance Impact ------------------ No significant performance impact. Other deployer impact --------------------- No other impact. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Louis Fourie (louis.fourie@huawei.com) Other contributors: Cathy Zhang Work Items ---------- The work items include: 1. Implement CRUD operations to specify a new resources. 2. Implement Database updates to support that API. 3. Implement Migration scripts to support the new DB items. 4. Implement python-neutronclient changes for CLI. 5. Implement Horizon changes. 6. Implement HEAT changes. Dependencies ============ This blueprint depends on Neutron services. Testing ======= Unit tests will be provided. Documentation Impact ==================== A description of the new attributes must be added to the documentation. References ========== None.

do-not-merge: test fuel-community-fuel-scenario

Change-Id: I2bccd27702aaad0743beb534387880422abda2c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/09/204209/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from rally.plugins.openstack.scenarios.fuel import nodes from tests.unit import test class FuelNodesTestCase(test.TestCase): context = {"fuel": {"environments": ["1"]}} def test_add_and_remove_nodes(self): scenario = nodes.FuelNodes(self.context) scenario._list_node_ids = mock.Mock(return_value=["1"]) scenario._node_is_assigned = mock.Mock(return_value=False) scenario._add_nodes = mock.Mock() scenario._remove_nodes = mock.Mock() scenario.add_and_remove_nodes(nodes_role="some_role") scenario._list_node_ids.assert_called_once_with() scenario._node_is_assigned.assert_called_once_with("1") scenario._add_nodes.assert_called_once_with("1", "1", "some_role") scenario._remove_nodes.assert_called_once_with("1", "1") def test_add_and_remove_nodes_error(self): scenario = nodes.FuelNodes(self.context) scenario._list_node_ids = mock.Mock(return_value=["1"]) scenario._node_is_assigned = mock.Mock(return_value=True) scenario._add_nodes = mock.Mock() scenario._remove_nodes = mock.Mock() self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, scenario.add_and_remove_nodes, nodes_role="some_role")

subject: [IBP] fix 'udevd: can not read' errors again
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-23 13:47:03.000000000', 'files': ['fuel_agent/fuel_agent/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/e91bb2e72be0124c13a0143945bbbe08e4bf0dcd', 'message': "[IBP] fix 'udevd: can not read' errors again

It looks like udev rule content is being delivered in a middle of
blacklisting routine. Adding sync in order to be sure that data is
written on disk.

Change-Id: I2613777b367fe29b5e35f06e00fdb9a644498cfc
Closes-Bug: #1422717
"}]
commit_message:
[IBP] fix 'udevd: can not read' errors again

It looks like udev rule content is being delivered in a middle of
blacklisting routine. Adding sync in order to be sure that data is
written on disk.

Change-Id: I2613777b367fe29b5e35f06e00fdb9a644498cfc
Closes-Bug: #1422717
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/42/176742/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: f.flush() os.fsync(f.fileno())

commit_message:
Increase default start timeout for Pacemaker from 20s to 90s

On slow environments the start operation of some services can
take longer than 20s so we increase the default for start
operation to 90s, more info can be found at:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1242052

Systemd defaults to 90s as well.

Change-Id: Ie4652bad518075be77937d47830f263034eda79c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/85/202085/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pacemaker::resource::service: op_params: 'start timeout=60s'

commit_message:
Avoiding an extra gap in the name of a test plan

In fuel-qa/fuelweb_test/testrail/report.py we have the following code
block http://paste.mirantis.net/show/769/. If the prefix variable is '',
the name of a test plan will have an extra gap. So other scripts (for
example, report_tempest_results.py), that publish some test results to
TestRail, always create new test plan because they try to find the name
of the test plan without the gap. That causes duplicating test plans and
that is very inconvenient for users.

Closes-Bug: #1476327

Change-Id: I1c087e835e63db4828fafb3b936f7ace2d4eb29d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/33/203733/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if prefix: test_plan_name = '{milestone} {prefix} iso #{iso_number}'.format( milestone=milestone['name'], iso_number=iso_number, prefix=prefix) else: test_plan_name = '{milestone} iso #{iso_number}'.format( milestone=milestone['name'], iso_number=iso_number, prefix=prefix)

commit_message:
Do not add @domain_name to dnsmasq.conf if it equals 'local'

Currently dnsmasq tries to resolve locally a host named
test.mydomain.local instead of forwarding this request to the local dns
server.

Change-Id: I5892fddaffa0dc619f0a54ac0f9fac34055b9b3f
Closes-Bug: 1411425
(cherry picked from commit 3ca3ef5aae68b84ec8b9beb55e552bdd70d42599)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/21/166221/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <% if @domain_name != 'local' %><% end %>

commit_message:
Hardcode the location of Horizon policy files on CentOS

By default Horizon looks for these files in ROOT_PATH/conf,
which is a symlink to [1] on CentOS. This results in displaying
unusable elements supposed to be shown only for administrator, without
listing objects that user has no access to.

[1] /usr/share/openstack-dashboard/openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py

Change-Id: I4e862384ec9c435ec7077633c8254c1c9f547b10
Closes-Bug: 1397069
(cherry picked from commit 2a46295071fed165bea78efe1d1a1a62488a5a65)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/74/145474/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # POLICY_FILES_PATH = os.path.join(ROOT_PATH, "conf") <% if @osfamily == 'redhat' %> POLICY_FILES_PATH = "/etc/openstack-dashboard/" <% end %>

commit_message:
Set nova's default_floating_pool

This is needed for `nova floating-ip-create` command to work without
specifying a particular external network. Probably not a big deal for
end users (usually you'd want to pick the network you want, and
e.g. `neutron floatingip-create` won't allow autoselection). However,
tempest depends on this functionality, so we should have it.

The value is specified in hiera (even though it's not a class parameter),
so that users can override it via ExtraConfig if need be.

Change-Id: I3967e0b8554482b34d089574fe028d2c7caaf669
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/83/203083/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nova_default_floating_pool: ext-net

revisions:

Ubuntu-minimal does not install openssh, but simple-init.sh expects it

Change-Id: I8585c6d0349413b2129a751a1e54e4e5734cb8fb
'}]
commit_message:
Dont fail simple-init without ssh installed

Ubuntu-minimal does not install openssh, but simple-init.sh expects it
to be there. Lets not fail if its missing.

Change-Id: I8585c6d0349413b2129a751a1e54e4e5734cb8fb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/60/194260/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: test -f /etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key || dpkg-reconfigure openssh-server || true

commit_message:
Add support hypermetro for huawei volume driver

Hypermetro is a key storage feature and a requirement for features
such as high-availability and disaster recovery of applications
running on top of OpenStack clouds. This blueprint is an attempt
to add initial support for volume hypermetro in Huawei volume driver.

Change-Id: I3d12d8766f617cc55afa0e08e028110e0993f1bd
Implements: blueprint support-hypermetro-for-huawei-volume-driver

added_lines: from oslo_utils import importutilsfrom cinder.i18n import _, _LE, _LI, _LW help='The configuration file for the Cinder Huawei driver'), cfg.StrOpt('hypermetro_devices', default=constants.HYPERMETRO_DEVICES, help='The remote device hypermetro will use.'), ] self.hypermetro_devices = self.configuration.hypermetro_devices opts = huawei_utils.get_volume_params(volume) # Update the medatata. Deal with hypermetro connection. metadata = huawei_utils.get_volume_metadata(volume) if 'hypermetro_id' in metadata: try: plugin = importutils.import_object(constants.HYPERMETRO, self.restclient, None, self.configuration) plugin.connect_volume_iscsi(volume, connector) except ImportError: LOG.error(_LE('Import hypermetro class error.')) # Deal with hypermetro disconnection. metadata = huawei_utils.get_volume_metadata(volume) if 'hypermetro_id' in metadata: try: plugin = importutils.import_object(constants.HYPERMETRO, self.restclient, None, self.configuration) plugin.disconnect_volume_iscsi(volume, connector) except ImportError: LOG.error(_LE('Import hypermetro class error.')) fc_info = HuaweiBaseDriver.initialize_connection_fc(self, volume, connector) loc_tgt_wwn = fc_info['data']['target_wwn'] # Deal with hypermetro connection. metadata = huawei_utils.get_volume_metadata(volume) LOG.info(_LI("initialize_connection, metadata is: %s."), metadata) if 'hypermetro_id' in metadata: try: plugin = importutils.import_object(constants.HYPERMETRO, self.restclient, None, self.configuration) remote_fc_info = plugin.connect_volume_fc(volume, connector) rem_tgt_wwn = remote_fc_info['data']['target_wwn'] fc_info['data']['target_wwn'] = loc_tgt_wwn + rem_tgt_wwn except ImportError as err: LOG.error(_LE('Import hypermetro class error:' ' %(err)s.'), {'err': err}) LOG.info(_LI("Return FC info is: %s."), fc_info) return fc_info def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs): fc_info = HuaweiBaseDriver.terminate_connection_fc(self, volume, connector) # Deal with hypermetro connection. metadata = huawei_utils.get_volume_metadata(volume) LOG.info(_LI("initialize_connection, metadata is: %s."), metadata) if 'hypermetro_id' in metadata: try: plugin = importutils.import_object(constants.HYPERMETRO, self.restclient, None, self.configuration) plugin.disconnect_volume_fc(volume, connector) except ImportError as err: LOG.error(_LE('Import hypermetro class error:' ' %(err)s.'), {'err': err}) return fc_info

commit_message:
Add patches for Cinder module to reach 6.0.0 (stable/kilo) version

  Head is 6.0.0 tag (stable/kilo):
  commit I56b87c8d63514caacdcfec51dc264711e547feb6

  There are no any custom changes.

  Partially implements: blueprint upgrade-openstack-puppet-modules

Change-Id: Ic45d385141816cd40fa06b58d67947f8dd4ce840

commit_message:
Removing archaic references

This document was originally imported from Nova. Removing some of the
old references to Quickstart and Hypervisors.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/cinder/devref/development.environment.html
has a dangling link to a ../quickstart document (removed long ago.)

Change-Id: If70f4cb45034e78304cd8c5c5d5deccb692d19e7
Closes-bug: #1225822

commit_message:
Neutron VxLAN support

The patch changes GRE in UI and Nailgun to more generic
TUN segmentation type, letting fuel-library decide what tunnels
to use (VxLAN will be used by default in 7.0)

Implements: blueprint neutron-vxlan-support

Change-Id: Ifa63b7f149dfa021aa5898674bc16c1955cdb787
Co-Authored-By: Oleg Bondarev <obondarev@mirantis.com>

Update openstack version to kilo in openstack.yaml

Update openstack_version: "2014.2.2-7.0" to "2015.1.0-7.0".

Fix test CI failures

* pin oslo.serialization<1.5.0
* pin oslo.config<=1.11.0

Closes-Bug: #1476704

commit_message:
Switch to oslo.service library

Modules eventlet_backdoor, loopingcall, periodic_task,
service, sslutils, systemd, threadgroup were removed
from nova. These modules were imported from oslo.service
library.

Co-Authored-By: Marian Horban <mhorban@mirantis.com>
Depends-On: I305cf53bad6213c151395e93d656b53a8a28e1db
Change-Id: Iaef67e16af3d69f845742f7bdcb43667bf1576ee

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2012 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging import threading import eventlet from eventlet import greenpool from nova.openstack.common._i18n import _LE from nova.openstack.common import loopingcall LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def _thread_done(gt, *args, **kwargs): """Callback function to be passed to GreenThread.link() when we spawn() Calls the :class:`ThreadGroup` to notify if. """ kwargs['group'].thread_done(kwargs['thread']) class Thread(object): """Wrapper around a greenthread, that holds a reference to the :class:`ThreadGroup`. The Thread will notify the :class:`ThreadGroup` when it has done so it can be removed from the threads list. """ def __init__(self, thread, group): self.thread = thread self.thread.link(_thread_done, group=group, thread=self) def stop(self): self.thread.kill() def wait(self): return self.thread.wait() def link(self, func, *args, **kwargs): self.thread.link(func, *args, **kwargs) class ThreadGroup(object): """The point of the ThreadGroup class is to: * keep track of timers and greenthreads (making it easier to stop them when need be). * provide an easy API to add timers. """ def __init__(self, thread_pool_size=10): self.pool = greenpool.GreenPool(thread_pool_size) self.threads = [] self.timers = [] def add_dynamic_timer(self, callback, initial_delay=None, periodic_interval_max=None, *args, **kwargs): timer = loopingcall.DynamicLoopingCall(callback, *args, **kwargs) timer.start(initial_delay=initial_delay, periodic_interval_max=periodic_interval_max) self.timers.append(timer) def add_timer(self, interval, callback, initial_delay=None, *args, **kwargs): pulse = loopingcall.FixedIntervalLoopingCall(callback, *args, **kwargs) pulse.start(interval=interval, initial_delay=initial_delay) self.timers.append(pulse) def add_thread(self, callback, *args, **kwargs): gt = self.pool.spawn(callback, *args, **kwargs) th = Thread(gt, self) self.threads.append(th) return th def thread_done(self, thread): self.threads.remove(thread) def _stop_threads(self): current = threading.current_thread() # Iterate over a copy of self.threads so thread_done doesn't # modify the list while we're iterating for x in self.threads[:]: if x is current: # don't kill the current thread. continue try: x.stop() except eventlet.greenlet.GreenletExit: pass except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Error stopping thread.')) def stop_timers(self): for x in self.timers: try: x.stop() except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Error stopping timer.')) self.timers = [] def stop(self, graceful=False): """stop function has the option of graceful=True/False. * In case of graceful=True, wait for all threads to be finished. Never kill threads. * In case of graceful=False, kill threads immediately. """ self.stop_timers() if graceful: # In case of graceful=True, wait for all threads to be # finished, never kill threads self.wait() else: # In case of graceful=False(Default), kill threads # immediately self._stop_threads() def wait(self): for x in self.timers: try: x.wait() except eventlet.greenlet.GreenletExit: pass except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Error waiting on ThreadGroup.')) current = threading.current_thread() # Iterate over a copy of self.threads so thread_done doesn't # modify the list while we're iterating for x in self.threads[:]: if x is current: continue try: x.wait() except eventlet.greenlet.GreenletExit: pass except Exception as ex: LOG.exception(ex)

commit_message:
Allow list_resource_types return a list of dict

This patch allows the list_resource_types() API to return a list of
dict where each dict contains the actual resource type representation.
It is proposed to make Heat conform to the API-WG recommendation:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/representation_structure.html#collection-resources
It also help remove the gate barrier to get resource type list patch
tested (patch here: https://review.openstack.org/147761/)

Change-Id: Icba48326b2f1286d55701a93f9c637eec508677b

added_lines: import six type_names = [] for restype in resource_types: if isinstance(restype, six.string_types): # for compatibility with old Heat API type_names.append(restype) else: type_names.append(restype['name']) self.assertIn('OS::Nova::Server', type_names) if isinstance(resource_type, six.string_types): # old resource type list where each is a string type_name = resource_type else: # resource_type is a dict in Heat API version 1.4+ type_name = resource_type['name'] type_schema = self.client.get_resource_type(type_name) self.assertEqual(type_name, type_schema['resource_type']) 'Parameters', 'Resources')

commit_message:
Remove HOT Reference Guide from docs.openstack.org

As per https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1461720,
the HOT Guide has been moved from the User Guide in the
openstack-manuals repo to the Template Guide in the Heat repo.

The Template Guide maintains a HOT reference chapter
(http://docs.openstack.org/developer/heat/template_guide/openstack.html)
that duplicates the HOT Reference guide
(http://docs.openstack.org/hot-reference/content/).
As such, it makes sense to remove the HOT Reference guide from
docs.openstack.org.

* remove hot-reference guide
* remove HOT Reference hyperlink from index
* update /www/static/.htaccess, redirect link

Closes-Bug: #1469606

Change-Id: Ie2240d2fca5d6e43b1d186645e7ff9107514f289

To get attribute values for a single resource in the group, synthetic attributes of the form <citetitle>resource.{resource index}.{attribute name}</citetitle> can be used. The resource ID of a particular resource in the group can be obtained via the synthetic attribute <citetitle>resource.{resource index}</citetitle>." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2871(para) msgid "While each resource in the group will be identically configured, this resource does allow for some index-based customization of the properties of the resources in the group. For example:" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2887(para) msgid "would result in a group of three servers having the same image and flavor, but names of <citetitle>my_server_0</citetitle>, <citetitle>my_server_1</citetitle>, and <citetitle>my_server_2</citetitle>. The variable used for substitution can be customized by using the <citetitle>index_var</citetitle> property." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2894(term) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4617(term) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4812(term) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:11529(term) msgid "count" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2896(para) msgid "The number of instances to create." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2903(term) msgid "index_var" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2908(para) msgid "A variable that this resource will use to replace with the current index of a given resource in the group. Can be used, for example, to customize the name property of grouped servers in order to differentiate them when listed with nova client." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2910(para) msgid "Optional property, defaults to "%index%"." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2911(para) msgid "The length must be at least 3." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2915(term) msgid "removal_policies" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2920(para) msgid "Policies for removal of resources on update" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2930(para) msgid "Policy to be processed when doing an update which requires removal of specific resources." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2938(term) msgid "resource_list" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2940(para) msgid "List of resources to be removed when doing an update which requires removal of specific resources. The resource may be specified several ways: (1) The resource name, as in the nested stack, (2) The resource reference returned from get_resource in a template, as available via the 'refs' attribute Note this is destructive on update when specified; even if the count is not being reduced, and once a resource name is removed, it's name is never reused in subsequent updates" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2952(term) msgid "resource_def" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:2954(para) msgid "Resource definition for the resources in the group. These input values are interpreted by the configuration tool in a tool-specific manner." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3654(para) msgid "Whenever this resource goes to an IN_PROGRESS state, it creates an ephemeral config that includes the inputs values plus a number of extra inputs which have names prefixed with deploy_. The extra inputs relate to the current state of the stack, along with the information and credentials required to signal back the deployment results." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3659(para) msgid "Unless signal_transport=NO_SIGNAL, this resource will remain in an IN_PROGRESS state until the server signals it with the output values for that deployment. Those output values are then available as resource attributes, along with the default attributes deploy_stdout, deploy_stderr and deploy_status_code." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3664(para) msgid "Specifying actions other than the default CREATE and UPDATE will result in the deployment being triggered in those actions. For example this would allow cleanup configuration to be performed during actions SUSPEND and DELETE. A config could be designed to only work with some specific actions, or a config can read the value of the deploy_action input to allow conditional logic to perform different configuration for different actions." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3677(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3815(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4298(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4459(para) msgid "Which stack actions will result in this deployment being triggered." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3680(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3818(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4301(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4462(para) msgid "Allowed values: CREATE, UPDATE, DELETE, SUSPEND, RESUME" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3686(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3824(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4307(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4468(para) msgid "ID of software configuration resource to execute when applying to the server." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3692(term) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3830(term) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4321(term) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4482(term) msgid "input_values" msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3694(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3832(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4323(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4484(para) msgid "Input values to apply to the software configuration on this server." msgstr "" #: ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3702(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:3840(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4340(para) ./doc/hot-reference/generated/openstack.xml:4501(para) msgid "Name of the derived config associated with this deployment. commit_message:
Minor readability changes to Chapter 9

Replace from 'a useable variable' to 'a variable'
on Chapter 9 of OpenStack Operations Guide
Closes-Bug: #1476589

Change-Id: I5834c771c457cf8ba388fe03adc6d1770273d13f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/57/204357/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Place the tenant ID in a variable:</para> <para>Place the tenant ID in a variable:</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Place the tenant ID in a useable variable, as follows:</para> <para>Place the tenant ID in a useable variable, as follows:</para>

subject: Fixes table when there are multiline in result data
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-22 02:34:16.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/9a289706e769af62ca4f57fa1d6a4f942ef9d788', 'message': 'Fixes table when there are multiline in result data

The table doesn't display right when there are multiple line in
result data. Fixes this by replace "\r" with "\t".

Change-Id: I5e02c4f1e5f5c89c240064cd8c869308debbc8b1
Closes-bug: #1476462
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes table when there are multiline in result data

The table doesn't display right when there are multiple line in
result data. Fixes this by replace "\r" with "\t".

Change-Id: I5e02c4f1e5f5c89c240064cd8c869308debbc8b1
Closes-bug: #1476462
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/42/204342/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (data and isinstance(data, six.string_types) and '\r' in data): data = data.replace('\r', '\t') if (value and isinstance(value, six.string_types) and '\r' in value): value = value.replace('\r', '\t')

commit_message:
Soft delete system_metadata when destroy instance

When destroy instance, the system_metadata is not deleted
and it will lead to problem db archieving issue.

Co-Authored-By: Alex Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>
Change-Id: Ie074c94a0f10bd42b7abed456a89bd513603d5d6
Partial-Bug: #1226049

added_lines: model_query(context, models.InstanceSystemMetadata, session=session).\ filter_by(instance_uuid=instance_uuid).\ soft_delete()

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-24 06:37:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/18a93da1baf70f38f0fd8127993c6f575b9ed17b', 'message': "Let soft-deleted instance_system_metadata readable

This is only for get review comments patch

we can't delete instance system metadata because
1) we might have 'changed-since' request which will access
the soft deleted system_metadata
2) we might has period audit function which also access the
soft deleted system_metadata

The root cause is the join function filtered the 'deleted'
data of system metadata and it lead to ValueError later.

Conceptually the system metadata is associated with instance,
it will be used in instance's lifecycle, the data will only
be updated so we won't have 2 copies or more system_metadata
for the same instance.
SO allow to read it even if it's deleted is safe.

Will propose more commit if it's acceptable solution.

commit_message:
Let soft-deleted instance_system_metadata readable

Currently, We can't delete instance system metadata after instance
is deleted because of following reason:
1) We might have 'changed-since' request which will access
the soft deleted system_metadata
2) We might has period audit function which also access the
soft deleted system_metadata

The root cause is the join function filtered the 'deleted'
data of system metadata and it lead to ValueError later.

Conceptually the system metadata is associated with instance,
it will be used in instance's lifecycle, the data will only
be updated so we won't have 2 copies or more system_metadata
for the same instance.
So allow to read it even if it's deleted is safe.

This patch load the system_metadata from db when instance is
in deleted state to avoid can't delete system_metadata issue.

Co-Authored-By: Alex Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>

Change-Id: Ifd8d2c91879834d3759aafdb036dac209a246d1b
Partial-Bug: #1226049

commit_message:
Add test case for policy base module and fix a bug

This patch added test case for policy base module. And it also
fixed a bug in from_dict method in this module.

Change-Id: Id2a892e829fc82d5156d82de1d4cb0548159a6c7
Closes-Bug: #1470305

commit_message:
Use url to check if ODL is fully initialized

With this change, releases of ODL that provide a url to know when
its fully operational will not need to unconditionally wait for
ODL_BOOT_WAIT before proceeding.

Note that in Kilo the lib function test_with_retry does not exist.
Thus, we create odl_test_with_retry.

Change-Id: I1a6fa4619489944b210586386bc3496c1cef26a1
(cherry picked from commit fab09304a11f1803a3fc98ec6c9512cf79038e42)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/82/203282/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Test with a finite retry loop. # NOTE: ONLY NEEDED in stable/kilo, already in # devstack master (commit: 442e4e96) # function odl_test_with_retry { local testcmd=$1 local failmsg=$2 local until=${3:-10} local sleep=${4:-0.5} if ! timeout $until sh -c "while ! $testcmd; do sleep $sleep; done"; then die $LINENO "$failmsg" fi } if [ -n "$ODL_BOOT_WAIT_URL" ]; then echo "Waiting for Opendaylight to start via $ODL_BOOT_WAIT_URL ..." # Probe ODL restconf for netvirt until it is operational local sleep_interval=3 local testcmd="curl -o /dev/null --fail --silent --head -u ${ODL_USERNAME}:${ODL_PASSWORD} http://${ODL_MGR_IP}:${ODL_PORT}/${ODL_BOOT_WAIT_URL}" odl_test_with_retry "$testcmd" "Opendaylight did not start after $ODL_BOOT_WAIT" $ODL_BOOT_WAIT $sleep_interval else echo "Waiting for Opendaylight to start ..." # Sleep a bit to let OpenDaylight finish starting up sleep $ODL_BOOT_WAIT fi
deleted_lines: # Sleep a bit to let OpenDaylight finish starting up sleep $ODL_BOOT_WAIT

revisions:

The Zanata documentation current specifies that the attribute to
set is 'pattern', but the code currently specifies 'apply-to'. Since
this keeps tripping me up, fix it in our code. This can be reverted
when a Zanata client fixing[1] is released.

Change-Id: Ifbe76588b85a4226253617ff8b723410d05de36c
1: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1241346
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-21 07:04:53.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/scripts/create-zanata-xml.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/68b38e9576e1865cdd632c9d895ebc658777b44e', 'message': 'Switch default pattern in create-zanata-xml.py

It turns out the Zanata client applies patterns relative to the
project root, and not the src-dir that is configured in zanata.xml.
Change the default pattern to be **/*.pot.

Change-Id: Ifbe76588b85a4226253617ff8b723410d05de36c
'}]
commit_message:
Switch default pattern in create-zanata-xml.py

It turns out the Zanata client applies patterns relative to the
project root, and not the src-dir that is configured in zanata.xml.
Change the default pattern to be **/*.pot.

Change-Id: Ifbe76588b85a4226253617ff8b723410d05de36c

added_lines: new_rule.attrib['apply-to'] = rule['pattern']

commit_message:
Adding angular-gettext to global requirements

Angular-gettext provides simple translation support for AngularJS.
We plan on using this in Horizon. See blueprint for additional details.

Change-Id: Ica8d73752093f2e5d30f70fc37ba87610f6823b1
Partially-Implements: blueprint angular-translate-makemessages

commit_message:
Get heat.tests.test_stack* working in py34 env

There are three tests skipped which needs further
addressing later on. However, fixing test_stack should prevent
future regressions for when a stack object is created.

commit_message:
Avoid the hard coding of admin token

The config provides a default value for the admin token, so the admin
token can be fetched from the config directly.

Change-Id: I0cb0738d0347ce07c06c28284579c028891eb4e2

commit_message:
Bump lower/upper constraint of futurist to newly released 0.1.2

Oslo.messaging and taskflow (and others) would like to take advantage
of functionality added into futurist in the 0.1.2 release so adjust
the needed version bounds to make that possible.

Change-Id: Ifd7b6e11863cae3d34fd5475a364ebb7c28811fc

commit_message:
Sort metric data before grouping and processing

In gnocchi dispatcher, metric data will be grouped by resource_id and
counter_name before processing. But the inputted data is an unordered
list. It is better being sorted by resource_id and counter_name before
processing.

Change-Id: I8f493f720c479fd84b1a554ee5196115b992ecd1

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-09 12:01:24.000000000', 'files': ['elements/debian/package-installs.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/ec2be8a75e88deb12eed6cee75e4a2549f9374e2', 'message': 'debian: install DHCP client and ifconfig packages

When building an image having the elements debian and vm, cloud-init
fails with:

    ci-info: !!!!!!!!Net device info failed!!!!!!!!

Looking at the source code, it executes ifconfig to gather informations
but the `debian` elements does not provide it.  There is also no DHCP
client available which is rather painful.

Install isc-dhcp-client to provide a DHCP client.
Install net-tools to provide ifconfig, required by cloud-init.

Ref: https://phabricator.wikimedia.org/T105152
Change-Id: I76dfd4f87a5c9f08e7c572fb4f5ebeeb34f5f66a
'}]
commit_message:
debian: install DHCP client and ifconfig packages

When building an image having the elements debian and vm, cloud-init
fails with:

    ci-info: !!!!!!!!Net device info failed!!!!!!!!

Looking at the source code, it executes ifconfig to gather informations
but the `debian` elements does not provide it.  There is also no DHCP
client available which is rather painful.

Install isc-dhcp-client to provide a DHCP client.
Install net-tools to provide ifconfig, required by cloud-init.

Ref: https://phabricator.wikimedia.org/T105152
Change-Id: I76dfd4f87a5c9f08e7c572fb4f5ebeeb34f5f66a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/30/200030/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fixed incorrect dhcp_server value during nova-network creation

When parameter dhcp_server is None, we must use network gateway
for each network. But because of incorrect usage of variable
dhcp_server, we use gateway of the FIRST network for each network.

Co-Authored-By: Roman Podoliaka <rpodolyaka@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Pavel Kholkin <pkholkin@mirantis.com>

Closes-Bug: #1443970

Change-Id: I9d22a2ac94e8675a231436ce8ba77260c4b8b98a
(cherry picked from commit f697befdd3a0f9b81ff9a74f55e4460cd3783692)

commit_message:
Moved the contents related to DataDrivenTests to a new directory

1. Created a new directory called 'ddt' to hold all the data
driven tests so that they could be scheduled to run independently
of the other tests.

2. Common functionalities used across the data driven tests
including  various resource setups and operating status checks
have been gathered up under v2/ddt/base_ddt.py file. (Earlier,
I made it a part of v2/api/base.py. Now, it's been pulled out to
the 'ddt' directory.)

Change-Id: I65867826683653a8d8969eee39a12b11e92c2019

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from tempest_lib.common.utils import data_utils import testscenarios from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.lib import config from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.lib import test from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.v2.api import base CONF = config.CONF LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) """ Tests the following operations in the Neutron-LBaaS API using the REST client with various combinations of values for the admin_state_up field of lb, listener, pool and member. create member update member """ class AdminStateTests(testscenarios.TestWithScenarios, base.BaseTestCase): @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(AdminStateTests, cls).resource_setup() if not test.is_extension_enabled("lbaas", "network"): msg = "lbaas extension not enabled." raise cls.skipException(msg) network_name = data_utils.rand_name('network-') cls.network = cls.create_network(network_name) cls.subnet = cls.create_subnet(cls.network) cls.tenant_id = cls.subnet.get('tenant_id') cls.subnet_id = cls.subnet.get('id') cls.protocol = 'HTTP' cls.port = 8081 cls.lb_algorithm = 'ROUND_ROBIN' cls.address = '127.0.0.1' @classmethod def resource_setup_load_balancer(cls, admin_state_up_flag): cls.create_lb_kwargs = {'tenant_id': cls.tenant_id, 'vip_subnet_id': cls.subnet_id, 'admin_state_up': admin_state_up_flag} cls.load_balancer = cls._create_active_load_balancer( **cls.create_lb_kwargs) cls.load_balancer_id = cls.load_balancer['id'] @classmethod def resource_setup_listener(cls, admin_state_up_flag): cls.create_listener_kwargs = {'loadbalancer_id': cls.load_balancer_id, 'protocol': cls.protocol, 'protocol_port': cls.port, 'admin_state_up': admin_state_up_flag } cls.listener = cls._create_listener( **cls.create_listener_kwargs) cls.listener_id = cls.listener['id'] @classmethod def resource_setup_pool(cls, admin_state_up_flag): cls.create_pool_kwargs = {'protocol': cls.protocol, 'lb_algorithm': cls.lb_algorithm, 'listener_id': cls.listener_id, 'admin_state_up': admin_state_up_flag } cls.pool = cls._create_pool( **cls.create_pool_kwargs) cls.pool_id = cls.pool['id'] @classmethod def resource_setup_member(cls, admin_state_up_flag): cls.create_member_kwargs = {'address': cls.address, 'protocol_port': cls.port, 'subnet_id': cls.subnet_id, 'admin_state_up': admin_state_up_flag} cls.member = cls._create_member( cls.pool_id, **cls.create_member_kwargs) cls.member_id = cls.member['id'] @classmethod def resource_set_health_monitor(cls, admin_state_up_flag): cls.create_hm_kwargs = {'type': cls.protocol, 'delay': 3, 'max_retries': 10, 'timeout': 5, 'pool_id': cls.pool_id, 'admin_state_up': admin_state_up_flag} cls.health_monitor = cls._create_health_monitor( **cls.create_hm_kwargs) cls.health_monitor_id = cls.health_monitor['id'] @classmethod def resource_cleanup(cls): super(AdminStateTests, cls).resource_cleanup() def check_lb_operating_status(self, load_balancer, listeners=None, pools=None, members=None, healthmonitor=None): if bool(load_balancer) and self.load_balancer.get('admin_state_up'): self.assertEqual( load_balancer.get('operating_status'), 'ONLINE') return True elif bool(load_balancer): self.assertEqual( load_balancer.get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(listeners): self.assertEqual(listeners[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(pools): self.assertEqual(pools[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(members): self.assertEqual(members[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(healthmonitor): self.assertEqual( healthmonitor.get('provisioning_status'), 'DISABLED') return False def check_listener_operating_status(self, listeners, pools=None, members=None, healthmonitor=None): if bool(listeners) and self.listener.get('admin_state_up'): self.assertEqual(listeners[0]. get('operating_status'), 'ONLINE') return True elif bool(listeners): self.assertEqual(listeners[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(pools): self.assertEqual(pools[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(members): self.assertEqual(members[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(healthmonitor): self.assertEqual( healthmonitor.get('provisioning_status'), 'DISABLED') return False def check_pool_operating_status(self, pools, members=None, healthmonitor=None): if bool(pools) and self.pool.get('admin_state_up'): self.assertEqual(pools[0]. get('operating_status'), 'ONLINE') return True elif bool(pools): self.assertEqual(pools[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(members): self.assertEqual(members[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') if bool(healthmonitor): self.assertEqual( healthmonitor.get('provisioning_status'), 'DISABLED') return False def check_member_operating_status(self, members): if bool(members) and self.member.get('admin_state_up'): self.assertEqual(members[0]. get('operating_status'), 'ONLINE') return True elif bool(members): self.assertEqual(members[0]. get('operating_status'), 'DISABLED') return False def check_health_monitor_provisioning_status(self, healthmonitor): if (bool(healthmonitor) and self.health_monitor.get('admin_state_up')): self.assertEqual( healthmonitor.get('provisioning_status'), 'ACTIVE') return True elif bool(healthmonitor): self.assertEqual( healthmonitor.get('provisioning_status'), 'DISABLED') return False def check_operating_status(self): statuses = (self.load_balancers_client. get_load_balancer_status_tree (self.load_balancer_id)) load_balancer = statuses['loadbalancer'] listeners = load_balancer['listeners'] pools = None members = None healthmonitor = None if bool(listeners): pools = listeners[0]['pools'] if bool(pools): members = pools[0]['members'] healthmonitor = pools[0]['healthmonitor'] if self.check_lb_operating_status(load_balancer, listeners, pools, members, healthmonitor): if self.check_listener_operating_status(listeners, pools, members, healthmonitor): if self.check_pool_operating_status(pools, members, healthmonitor): self.check_member_operating_status(members) self.check_health_monitor_provisioning_status( healthmonitor)

subject: Remove gate-tempest-dsvm-docker from nova's check queue
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-21 21:13:35.000000000', 'files': ['zuul/layout.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/8305c3b0bc981655caebdaeac484e39fd0209d67', 'message': "Remove gate-tempest-dsvm-docker from nova's check queue

The gate-tempest-dsvm-docker job fails most of the time on nova changes
and nobody from the nova-docker project is monitoring the job, so the
nova team wants it removed from the check queue for nova changes.

Change-Id: Ic8eae3b73601518616f9a32236663865024e76cd
"}]
commit_message:
Remove gate-tempest-dsvm-docker from nova's check queue

The gate-tempest-dsvm-docker job fails most of the time on nova changes
and nobody from the nova-docker project is monitoring the job, so the
nova team wants it removed from the check queue for nova changes.

This was discussed at the nova liberty midcycle meetup.

Change-Id: Ic8eae3b73601518616f9a32236663865024e76cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/64/204264/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deployments running versions before Kilo.

added_lines: ============ Introduction ============ The OpenStack Security Guide is the result of a five day sprint of collaborative work of many individuals. The purpose of this document is to provide the best practice guidelines for deploying a secure OpenStack cloud. It is a living document that is updated as new changes are merged into the repository, and is meant to reflect the current state of security within the OpenStack community and provide frameworks for decision making where listing specific security controls are not feasible due to complexity or other environment specific details.

subject: BDM: Stop booting if a blank volume as boot device
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-06 09:21:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a5c93c8b2d36cb42ea9d54e903976a379278c1b4', 'message': "BDM: Stop booting if a blank volume as vda

If booting an instance with block_device_mapping_v2 with follow command:

--block-device source=blank,dest=volume,device=vda,size=2

nova will only create one block device as boot device without local temporary
disk, even we can see from the request body we pass 2 block device mapping:

{u'source_type': u'image', u'destination_type': u'local', u'boot_index': 0,...}
{u'source_type': u'blank', u'destination_type': u'volume', ...
 u'device_name': u'vda'}

this command line is incorrect which should be refused.

Closed-Bug: #1449858

commit_message:
BDM: Stop booting if a blank volume as boot device

If booting an instance with block_device_mapping_v2 with follow command:
--block-device source=blank,dest=volume,device=vda,size=2
nova will only create one block device as boot device without local temporary
disk, even we can see from the request body we pass 2 block device mapping:
{u'source_type': u'image', u'destination_type': u'local', u'boot_index': 0,...}
{u'source_type': u'blank', u'destination_type': u'volume', ...
 u'device_name': u'vda'}
this command line is incorrect which should be refused.
Closed-Bug: #1449858
Change-Id: Ie50be8a2e4f6aaaac0f422bef5c4fd66dabe8b42

commit_message:
Remove py26 from tox

The Python 2.6 testing has been deprecated for some time, and is
removed from gate https://review.openstack.org/#/c/201105/.

This patch removes py26 from tox conf so that developers will not
end up testing py26.

Co-Authored-By: Sirushti Murugesan <sirushti.murugesan@hp.com>

Change-Id: Id2698c892db07278f47dea54360e8a0c4dad6981
Closes-Bug: #1474686

commit_message:
Added functional tests for L3 schedulers.

Legacy mode agents considered.

Following test cases are added:
Common scenarios:
1. No routers scheduled if no agents are present
2. No routers scheduled if it is already hosted
3. No routers scheduled if all agents are down
4. Router scheduled to the agent if router is not yet hosted
5. Router scheduled to the agent even if it already hosts a router

Following scenario specific to least routers scheduler is added:
1. Router is scheduled to agent hosting least routers

For each of Chance and Least Router schedulers auto scheduling is also verified.

A total of 22 test cases are added.

Change-Id: Ic4df299bac83c80abf0890a81d2dd36d15993b33
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/99/177499/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import random import testscenarios from neutron import context from neutron.scheduler import l3_agent_scheduler from neutron.tests.unit import test_db_plugin from neutron.tests.unit import test_l3_plugin from neutron.tests.unit import test_l3_schedulers # Required to generate tests from scenarios. Not compatible with nose. load_tests = testscenarios.load_tests_apply_scenarios class L3SchedulerBaseTest(test_db_plugin.NeutronDbPluginV2TestCase, test_l3_schedulers.L3SchedulerBaseMixin): """Base class for functional test of L3 schedulers. Provides basic setup and utility functions. """ def setUp(self): ext_mgr = test_l3_plugin.L3TestExtensionManager() plugin_str = ('neutron.tests.unit.test_l3_plugin.' 'TestL3NatIntAgentSchedulingPlugin') super(L3SchedulerBaseTest, self).setUp(plugin=plugin_str, ext_mgr=ext_mgr) self.adminContext = context.get_admin_context() def _create_l3_agent(self, host, context, agent_mode='legacy', plugin=None, state=True): agent = self._register_l3_agent(host, agent_mode, plugin) self._set_l3_agent_admin_state(self.adminContext, agent.id, state) return agent def _create_router(self, name): self.adminContext.tenant_id = '_func_test_tenant_' router = {'name': name, 'admin_state_up': True} return self.plugin.create_router(self.adminContext, {'router': router}) class L3ChanceSchedulerTestCase(L3SchedulerBaseTest): """Test various scenarios for chance schedule. agent_count Number of l3 agents (also number of hosts). down_agent_count Number of l3 agents which are down. scheduled_router_count Number of routers that have been previously scheduled. expected_scheduled_router_count Number of newly scheduled routers. """ scenarios = [ ('No routers scheduled if no agents are present', dict(agent_count=0, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=0, expected_scheduled_router_count=0)), ('No routers scheduled if it is already hosted', dict(agent_count=1, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=1, expected_scheduled_router_count=0)), ('No routers scheduled if all agents are down', dict(agent_count=2, down_agent_count=2, scheduled_router_count=0, expected_scheduled_router_count=0)), ('Router scheduled to the agent if router is not yet hosted', dict(agent_count=1, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=0, expected_scheduled_router_count=1)), ('Router scheduled to the agent even if it already hosts a router', dict(agent_count=1, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=1, expected_scheduled_router_count=1)), ] def _create_legacy_agents(self): # Creates legacy l3 agents and sets admin state based on # down agent count. self.hosts = ['host-%s' % i for i in range(self.agent_count)] self.l3_agents = [self._create_l3_agent(self.hosts[i], self.adminContext, 'legacy', self.plugin, (i >= self.down_agent_count)) for i in range(self.agent_count)] def _create_routers(self): self.routers = [] for i in range(self.scheduled_router_count + self.expected_scheduled_router_count): router = self._create_router('schd_rtr' + str(i)) self.routers.append(router) def setUp(self): super(L3ChanceSchedulerTestCase, self).setUp() self._create_legacy_agents() self._create_routers() self.scheduler = l3_agent_scheduler.ChanceScheduler() def test_chance_schedule_router(self): # schedule routers before calling schedule: for i in range(self.scheduled_router_count): router = self.routers[i] # chance scheduler will schedule randomly: agent = random.choice(self.l3_agents) self.scheduler.bind_router(self.adminContext, router['id'], agent) # The router to schedule: router_to_schedule = None if self.routers: # Last router is the one to be scheduled, # others, if any, have been scheduled already. router_to_schedule = self.routers[-1] else: # For cases where no router is scheduled or expected. router_to_schedule = self._create_router('schd_rtr') # schedule: actual_scheduled_agent = self.scheduler.schedule(self.plugin, self.adminContext, router_to_schedule['id']) if self.expected_scheduled_router_count: self.assertIsNotNone(actual_scheduled_agent, message='Failed to schedule agent') else: self.assertIsNone(actual_scheduled_agent, message='Agent scheduled but not expected') def test_auto_schedule_routers(self): # schedule routers before calling schedule: for i in range(self.scheduled_router_count): router = self.routers[i] # chance scheduler will schedule randomly: agent = random.choice(self.l3_agents) self.scheduler.bind_router(self.adminContext, router['id'], agent) # There must be at least one router to schedule if not self.routers: self.routers.append(self._create_router('schd_rtr')) router_ids = [rtr['id'] for rtr in self.routers] did_it_schedule = False # Try scheduling on each host for host in self.hosts: did_it_schedule = self.scheduler.auto_schedule_routers(self.plugin, self.adminContext, host, router_ids) if did_it_schedule: break if self.expected_scheduled_router_count: self.assertTrue(did_it_schedule, 'Failed to schedule agent') else: self.assertFalse(did_it_schedule, 'Agent scheduled, not expected') class L3LeastRoutersSchedulerTestCase(L3SchedulerBaseTest): """Test various scenarios for least router schedule. agent_count Number of l3 agents (also number of hosts). down_agent_count Number of l3 agents which are down. scheduled_router_count Number of routers that have been previously scheduled expected_scheduled_router_count Number of newly scheduled routers """ scenarios = [ ('No routers scheduled if no agents are present', dict(agent_count=0, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=0, expected_scheduled_router_count=0)), ('No routers scheduled if it is already hosted', dict(agent_count=1, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=1, expected_scheduled_router_count=1)), ('No routers scheduled if all agents are down', dict(agent_count=2, down_agent_count=2, scheduled_router_count=0, expected_scheduled_router_count=0)), ('Router scheduled to the agent if router is not yet hosted', dict(agent_count=1, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=0, expected_scheduled_router_count=1)), ('Router scheduled to the agent even if it already hosts a router', dict(agent_count=1, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=1, expected_scheduled_router_count=1)), ('Router is scheduled to agent hosting least routers', dict(agent_count=2, down_agent_count=0, scheduled_router_count=1, expected_scheduled_router_count=1)), ] def _create_legacy_agents(self): # Creates legacy l3 agents and sets admin state based on # down agent count. self.hosts = ['host-%s' % i for i in range(self.agent_count)] self.l3_agents = [self._create_l3_agent(self.hosts[i], self.adminContext, 'legacy', self.plugin, (i >= self.down_agent_count)) for i in range(self.agent_count)] def _create_routers(self): self.routers = [] for i in range(self.scheduled_router_count + self.expected_scheduled_router_count): router = self._create_router('schd_rtr' + str(i)) self.routers.append(router) def setUp(self): super(L3LeastRoutersSchedulerTestCase, self).setUp() self._create_legacy_agents() self._create_routers() self.scheduler = l3_agent_scheduler.LeastRoutersScheduler() def test_least_routers_schedule(self): # Schedule routers before calling schedule. hosting_agents = [] for i in range(self.scheduled_router_count): router = self.routers[i] # chance scheduler will schedule randomly: agent = random.choice(self.l3_agents) self.scheduler.bind_router(self.adminContext, router['id'], agent) hosting_agents.append(agent) # The router to schedule: router_to_schedule = None if self.routers: # Last router is the one to be scheduled, # others, if any, have been scheduled already. router_to_schedule = self.routers[-1] else: # For cases where no router is scheduled or expected. router_to_schedule = self._create_router('schd_rtr') actual_scheduled_agent = self.scheduler.schedule(self.plugin, self.adminContext, router_to_schedule['id']) if self.expected_scheduled_router_count: # For case where there is just one agent: if self.agent_count == 1: self.assertIs(actual_scheduled_agent, self.l3_agents[0]) else: self.assertNotIn(actual_scheduled_agent, hosting_agents, message='The expected agent was not scheduled') else: self.assertIsNone(actual_scheduled_agent, message='Expeced no agent to be scheduled,' ' but it got scheduled') def test_auto_schedule_routers(self): # schedule routers before calling schedule: for i in range(self.scheduled_router_count): router = self.routers[i] # chance scheduler will schedule randomly: agent = random.choice(self.l3_agents) self.scheduler.bind_router(self.adminContext, router['id'], agent) # There must be at least one router to schedule if not self.routers: self.routers.append(self._create_router('schd_rtr')) router_ids = [rtr['id'] for rtr in self.routers] did_it_schedule = False # Try scheduling on each host for host in self.hosts: did_it_schedule = self.scheduler.auto_schedule_routers(self.plugin, self.adminContext, host, router_ids) if did_it_schedule: break if self.expected_scheduled_router_count: self.assertTrue(did_it_schedule, 'Failed to schedule agent') else: self.assertFalse(did_it_schedule, 'Agent scheduled, not expected')

commit_message:
Huawei driver support storage pools

Change create_share function: Modify the get pool name method from
huawei configuration file to use manila.share.utils.extract_host
function.
Change update_share_stats function: One huawei backend can report
many pools.

Change-Id: Id6bb9c756f5871b4a9bc473b3e8f513c1792eee0
Implements: blueprint huawei-driver-dynamic-storage-pools

Parse exception from SDK

Some exceptions from SDK are not in stardard json format,
this patch parse it to json.

Partial-Bug: #1472557

subject: Support querying deleted alarms
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-21 08:07:58.000000000', 'files': ['specs/liberty/support-deleted-alarms-query.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs/commit/a08f8d0543193b5d9461ffa9a020c8a24414d825', 'message': 'Support querying deleted alarms

blueprint support-deleted-alarms-query

Change-Id: If729f8eed1de82ac6b18ddd8f0e72dc48b83e86a
'}]
commit_message:
Support querying deleted alarms

blueprint support-deleted-alarms-query

Change-Id: If729f8eed1de82ac6b18ddd8f0e72dc48b83e86a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/64/203964/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== Support querying deleted alarms =============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/support-deleted-alarms-query The alarm definition will be deleted in storage backend when users deleting the alarm, but the history of this alarm will still be stored in storage. It is hard for users to query the alarm history because alarm_id is needed in alarm history query. This proposal want to allow admin users query deleted alarms, and this is convenient for querying the history of deleted alarms. Problem description =================== The alarms history record the actions of alarms, the actions include creation, rule change, state transition and deletion. But, after deleting a alarm, the alarm will be deleted in storage backend (using mysql) and the alarm's history will still be stored in storage, there is no other solution to query the deleted alarm's history except querying the alarm id in alarm_history db table manually, because we need specifying alarm_id to query alarm history. So it's better to support the alarm definitions soft deleting, marking alarm as 'deleted' when deleted. And also, it's need to allow admin users listing deleted alarms by specifying 'deleted' query option. Proposed change =============== * keep the alarm definition in storage and mark it as 'deleted' after deletion. * allow admin users listing deleted alarms via API by specifying 'deleted' option. * apply the ttl mechanism to deleted alarms data. NOTE: these proposed changes will be implemented in Aodh code tree. Alternatives ------------ * Delete the corresponding alarm history when deleting a alarm. Data model impact ----------------- Add 'deleted' field to Alarm model. REST API impact --------------- An optional query option 'deleted' will be added to allow admin users to query deleted alarms. Security impact --------------- None. Pipeline impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: liusheng Other contributors: None Ongoing maintainer: liusheng Work Items ---------- * Add the soft-deletion of alarm definitions in storage layer. * Implement the deleted alarms query functionality in API layer. * Add the ttl mechanism for deleted alarm definitions data. Future lifecycle ================ None. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= We need to add tests for the API change and storage change. Documentation Impact ==================== User guide and developer documentation need to describe this functionality. References ========== None

added_lines: The choice of database server is an important consideration in the security of an OpenStack deployment. Multiple factors should be considered when deciding on a database server, however for the scope of this book only security considerations will be discussed. OpenStack supports a variety of database types (see `OpenStack Cloud Administrator Guide <http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud>`__ for more information). The Security Guide currently focuses on PostgreSQL and MySQL.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/12/204212/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Message queuing Message queuing services facilitate inter-process communication in OpenStack. OpenStack supports these message queuing service back ends: - RabbitMQ - Qpid - ZeroMQ or 0MQ Both RabbitMQ and Qpid are Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) frameworks, which provide message queues for peer-to-peer communication. Queue implementations are typically deployed as a centralized or decentralized pool of queue servers. ZeroMQ provides direct peer-to-peer communication through TCP sockets. Message queues effectively facilitate command and control functions across OpenStack deployments. Once access to the queue is permitted no further authorization checks are performed. Services accessible through the queue do validate the contexts and tokens within the actual message payload. However, you must note the expiration date of the token because tokens are potentially re-playable and can authorize other services in the infrastructure. OpenStack does not support message-level confidence, such as message signing. Consequently, you must secure and authenticate the message transport itself. For high-availability (HA) configurations, you must perform queue-to-queue authentication and encryption. With ZeroMQ messaging, IPC sockets are used on individual machines. Because these sockets are vulnerable to attack, ensure that the cloud operator has secured them.
